million to the Republic of the Philippines for the Technical Education

Rationale

The Project will assist the Government in  (i)  strengthening  the  role
and  capacity  of  the  Technical  Education  and  Skills  Development
Authority  (TESDA),  (ii)  devolving  TESDA’s  responsibilities  for  training
institutions  to  local  government  units  (LGUs),  (iii)  strengthening  the
capacity of the private providers of TESD, and (iv) enhancing equity in
skills acquisition among the poor. To effect these changes, the Project
will  prepare  TESDA-administered  institutions  for  devolution,  and
upgrade  the  curricula,  delivery  systems,  and  facilities  of  about  25
public TESD institutions and 45 provincial training centers.

The Project will institutionalize quality assurance programs in public
and private institutions. To enhance access to TESD programs the
Project will establish a scholarship fund and a student loan fund for
the  poor.  The  Project  will  strengthen  technical,  pedagogical,  and
management training at the school and local levels.

Project Description

Enrollments in private TESD institutions represent approximately 80 percent
of the total number of students in the TESD subsector. As part of component
(iii) of the TESDP, ADB will provide a loan of Y2,166,700,000 to DBP to set
up and manage the FTESD. DBP will provide subloans to private institutions
nationwide to upgrade the quality of their TESD programs. DBP will monitor

FTESD with  loan amounts  ranging from $25,000  to  $500,000.  The  majority
want  to  borrow between $75,000  and  $250,000.  Approximately  120  private

Competitiveness and the Labor Force3

5.
The competitiveness of Philippine manufacturing in global markets is centrally important
to  continued  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  As  noted  in  The  Philippine  National
Development  Plan:  Directions  for  the  21st  Century,4  economic  growth  and  modernization  can
accelerate  much  faster  when  there  is  sufficient  access  to  the  world’s  markets,  resources  and
know-how. However, if industry remains inefficient and uncompetitive, liberalization may lead to
a  net  income  loss  and a  widening  of  the gap between  rich and poor. Accordingly,  the  goal  of
meeting the challenges of globalization has been coupled with the goal of reducing poverty and
inequality.

The comparative advantage of the Philippines in the future lies not in unskilled labor, but

low-end  “high-tech”  areas  such  as  electronics  manufacturing  and  software
in 
development. Data show high growth rates in exports of products requiring skilled labor and  a
very low growth or stagnation of those based on unskilled labor. There has been a sharp decline
in  resource-based  manufactures, a  steady decline  in  labor-intensive  products,  and  a  dramatic
increase  in  science-based  goods,  including  those  that  are  technologically  complex.  For
example, the Philippines is now the second largest exporter of software in Asia after India. The
world market for software exports is vast and growing.5

7.
The  Philippines  is  competitive  in  skill-intensive  products  because  of  a  relatively  large
educated and trainable workforce. The country has considerable headroom for further growth in
value-added  manufactured products  owing  to  the  strong  world demand for  such  products,  the
current  small  market  share,  and  lack  of  vulnerability  to  easy  entry  by  low-wage  producers.
Considerable scope also exists for upgrading production facilities and the skills of the workforce.
However,  the  base  of  growth  remains  narrow  and  the  high  degree  of  export  concentration  is
cause  for  concern.  The  export-oriented  sector  has  relatively  shallow  roots  in  the  domestic
economy,  with  low  local  content  and few  technological  linkages.  In  strengthening  these  roots,
the  Philippines  should adopt policies to  ensure  technological and  skills upgrading6  and aim  to
increase the value added of its products. This strategy has major implications for TESD. Raising
productivity, essential for improved competitiveness, depends largely on improving the quality of
education and training at postbasic levels.7

8.
The  Philippines  faces  substantial  challenges  to  successfully  compete  in  the  world
market.  Sustained  growth  in  the  global  markets  will  require  deepening  of  the  technological
competence  of  enterprises and  workers.  Increases  in  skills  and  productivity  of  the  labor  force
are  necessary  to  increase  the  quality  and  value  of  output  without  raising  labor  costs  beyond
competitive levels. Higher productivity also leads to better earnings that enable workers to share
in the benefits of growth.

2.

Poverty Reduction

The second major challenge for the Philippines is to raise the productivity and incomes
11.
of the poorer segments of the population. The Philippines has made some progress in reducing
the incidence of poverty from 35.5 percent of households in 1994 to 32.1 percent in 1997. For
the population as a whole, poverty incidence declined from 40.6 percent in 1994 to 37.5 percent
in 1997. This means that in 1997, 27.25 million Filipinos fell below the official poverty line of an
annual per capita income of $285 equivalent (P11,388). In general, poverty incidence levels in
rural  areas  in  each  geographic  region  are  higher  than  in  urban  areas.  Mindanao  remains  the
poorest  area  with  50.9  percent  of  the  population  below  the  poverty  line,  compared  with
45.4 percent in Visayas, 35.7 percent in Luzon, and 9.6 percent in the National Capital Region.
The difference between urban and rural areas is stark: 18.5 percent of the population in urban
areas have annual income below the poverty line compared with 44.4 percent in rural areas.9

Skills training in the Philippines has three distinguishing characteristics: (i) the existence
15.
of  a  comprehensive  agency  (i.e.,  TESDA)  overseeing  all  levels  and  types  of  training,  (ii)  a
complex network of training providers, and (iii) the high proportion of skills training provided by
the private sector.

16.
 TESD is coordinated by a  single agency  (TESDA)  covering  all aspects  of  the  system,
including  school-based,  center-based,  community-based,  and  enterprise-based  training.  In
1994, by recommendation of the Congressional Commission on Education, all types of  middle
level  skills development  (MLSD)  were  integrated  under  TESDA.  TESDA  combined  the  former
Bureau of Technical and Vocational Education under the Department of Education, Culture and
Sports (DECS), the former National Manpower and Youth Council dealing with nonformal skills
training; and apprenticeship training programs of the Department of Labor and Employment.

17.
The structure of TESD is complex. Nearly all preemployment TESD training takes place
after  the  completion  of  secondary  school.  Training  is  delivered  in  a  bewildering  array  of
institutions,  including  schools,  institutes,  and  colleges.  Each  may  include  multiple  levels  and
types  of  programs  including  secondary,  postsecondary,  degree,  and  even  postgraduate
courses. A comparatively large share of skills training is provided in tertiary institutions, perhaps
reflecting the short duration of the basic education cycle (only 10 years, with the result that high
school  graduates  are  young)  and  also  the  high  cultural  value  attached  to  certification.  Public
state  universities  and  colleges  (SUCs)  absorb  more  than  half  of  the  total  public  spending  on
TESD.

18.
 Sixty percent of all training institutions are private but they accommodate 80 percent of
total enrollments in institution-based middle-level skills development. This makes the Philippines
unique in the world. Private TESD is financed almost exclusively from nonpublic sources, mainly
by  tuition  fees  and  endowment  income.  In  contrast  with  other  countries,  there  is  little  or  no
government subsidy12 for private training.

19.
In  addition,  sizable  firms  in  the  manufacturing  sector  show  surprising  dynamism  in
training their own workers. A recent survey shows that 60 percent of firms provided systematic
training for employees and invested significantly in training.13 Virtually all those firms employed
more than 50 persons. Smaller firms also provide training, although less often and less formally,

a.

TESDA’s Role, Responsibilities, and Capacity for Management

22.
TESDA was established in 1994 as a policy and quality-assurance agency for postbasic
TESD.14  In  the  first  years  of  its  existence,  much  of  TESDA’s  attention  was  consumed  by  the
need  to  integrate  various  organizational  units  and  the  first  year  of  full  operation  was  1997.
TESDA’s  mandate  as  the  national  training  authority  is  to  establish  a  supportive  policy
environment  for  middle-level  skills  development;  to  improve  quality  through  standards,
accreditation  and  monitoring,  research  and  development,  and  technical  assistance;  and  to
ensure equity in the training system. The bulk of  TESD  will  continue  to  come from  the private
sector and from enterprises that offer training on the job. Accordingly, TESDA’s role in training
needs  to  be  rationalized.  TESDA  inherited  the  administration  of  58  technical  and  vocational
schools  and  about 60  nonformal  training  centers.  The  operation  of  training  centers  consumes
about  two  thirds  of  TESDA’s budget and  considerable  staff  time.  It  is  not  appropriate  that  the
agency that accredits and supervises training institutions also runs them. 

Another  issue  of  management  effectiveness  concerns  a  major  gap  in  the  breadth  of
23.
TESDA’s  role  in  middle-level  skills  supervision.  TESDA  is  charged  with  providing  professional
oversight  of  all  middle-level  skills  development—formal  and  nonformal—including  semiskilled,
skilled,  and  technician  levels.  TESDA  has  oversight  responsibility  for  private  formal  and
nonformal education  mainly  through  its  registration  and  accreditation  system.  However,  it  has
no mechanism to provide input and guidance into the  various  kinds of  training provided  within
SUCs.

In sum, TESDA needs to rationalize its operations—including divesting its responsibility
24.
for direct administration of training operations, making the process of standards and certification
more  efficient,  placing  more  emphasis  on  its  supporting  role  in  systems  monitoring  and
information  dissemination,  and  closing  gaps  in  its  span  of  supervision.  Once  this  process  of
rationalization  is  completed,  TESDA  will  have  freed  up  staff  resources  for  higher  priority
activities,  including  policy  and  standards  development,  training  materials  support,  and  overall
monitoring  of  the  system.  One  priority  area  is  in  information  systems  and  data  collection  to
improve  the  information  base  for  research  on  TESD.  The  existing  management  information

b.

Quality and Relevance of TESD

25.
The  performance  of  the  TESD  system  is  best  measured  by  the  employment  rates  of
graduates,  but  little  current  information exists about  the  performance  of  the  system  in  placing
graduates  in  employment.  Many  administrators  of  TESD  schools  and  centers  stated  that  the
graduates  are  too  mobile  to  be  tracked  systematically  after  graduation.  Data  from  the  early
1990s,  as  quoted  in  the  1994  Congressional  Commission  on  Education  report,  claim  that
absorption rates at all levels and types of TESD were low. Employment rates were 31 percent
among  graduates  of  postsecondary  nondegree  courses.  The  best  performance  was  by
graduates from schools with short-term (generally nonformal) courses who achieve a 54 percent
employment  rate.16  Placement  rates  increased  substantially  in  the  mid-1990s  as  job  creation
surged  and  employment  prospects  brightened.  Anecdotal  evidence  supports  this.  Institutions
quote  absorption  rates  from  50  percent  upward  to  95  percent  for  the  better  institutions.
However, employment rates appear to have declined during the economic downturn of the late
1990s.  This  remains  speculative  until  more  data  are  collected.  TESDA  needs  to  do  more,
directly  or  through  schools,  to  collect  timely  and  reliable  information  about  the  employment
status  and  economic  performance  of  TESD  graduates  of  institutions  of  various  types  and
locations.

26.
TESDA  has  introduced  trade  testing  almost  exclusively  for  skills  at  the  technician  and
middle-level craftsman level. More than 220 trade tests have been developed. Their scope and
depth  are  considered  appropriate  as  they  are  validated  by  employers.  The  tests  are  taken
mainly by students completing their studies, rather than workers in employment. The tests give
a  useful  proxy  measure  of  the  quality  of  skills  attainment  of  the  graduates.  Unfortunately,  the
performance  achievements  are  not  high.  Only  about  49  percent  of  those  who  took  the
examinations  in  1995  passed,  and  the  average  declined  to  38  percent  in  1998.  This
exceptionally low result is a worrisome indicator of pervasive low quality in the system.

One explanation for low quality is the wide variance in inputs needed for high standards
27.
in training. Trainers tend to have strong academic qualifications, but lack skills qualifications and
industrial  experience.  Only  about  30  percent  of  the  trainers  had  trade  certification  and  only
9 percent  had  industrial  experience.17  Both  private  and  public  institutions  tend  to  suffer  from
shortages of equipment and budgets for consumable training supplies.

28.
The program of skill testing, valuable as an exit standard of quality attained, needs to be
extended  to  cover  more  occupations  and  expanded  by  establishing  more  testing  centers
throughout the country.

30.
TESDA has taken initiatives to improve the situation in three areas. It has introduced a
system19 of registration and accreditation designed to ensure that new programs and institutions
meet minimum levels of quality. Both private and public institutions must seek advance approval
for  all  courses  and  pass  a  minimum  threshold  for  authorization.  If  sensibly  administered,  this
system promises to stimulate substantial changes and improvements in private education. It will
eliminate some of the fly-by-night operators of doubtful repute. It will cause others to merge or

31.
TESDA has converted TESD programs to a system of competency-based training, which
involves  employers  in  identifying  competencies  required  for  particular  occupations  and
developing training modules focused on achieving those outputs. Competency-based training is
part  of  the  new  registration  and  accreditation  program.  This  system  promises  to  make  TESD
more effective by focusing on the essentials and eliminating unnecessary content from training.
TESDA  is  also  providing  positive  incentives  for  quality  improvement  in  training  through  its
annual  awards  for  training  excellence.  These  provide  considerable  leverage  on  the  system
without much cost.

32.
Other initiatives include TESDA’s role in the  development  of  trade  standards.  Over  the
past  two  years  TESDA,  with  industry  participation,  has  identified  seven  priority  sectors  and
developed 13 training regulations comprising trade standards plus competency-based curricula,
which will be gradually introduced. The standards will enable training institutions and employers
to assess the quality of graduates more objectively based on the identified competencies.

33.
Programs  for  quality  assurance  are  embryonic.  TESDA  has  initiated  several  programs
designed  to  improve  the  quality  and  relevance  of  TESD  systemwide,  but  needs  much  more
support  to  be  able  to  implement  them  properly.  Specifically,  assistance  is  needed  to  support
TESDA  in  programming,  refining,  and  implementing  these  quality  improvement  programs.  In
addition, substantial capital investment is needed to replenish and update equipment and train
staff in new fields and training methodologies.

d.

Inequitable Access

The  TESD  system enrolls  a  large  share  of  students  from  poor  households.  One  study
37.
found that three fourths of the students in TESD came from low-income families.23  More recent
observations found the range of students from poor backgrounds to be 60-90 percent (Appendix
B). Skills development is an important means for disadvantaged people to improve their income
and  quality  of  life.  However,  three  sets  of  barriers  impede  upward  mobility:  financial  barriers,
geographic and gender barriers, and structural impediments.

38.
First,  lack  of  finance  limits  access  to  TESD  programs  for  a  large  number  of  the  poor.
Even  with  the  currently  low  tuition  fees  in  public  institutions,  poor  families  without  stable

attending  TESD  institutions.  The  situation  is  more  difficult  when  the  poorer  children  attend
private  institutions  that  charge  student  fees  higher  than  those  in  public  schools.  Although  the

according to a formula that takes into account poverty incidence in the area. More than 10,700
scholarships were  awarded  in  school  year  (SY)  1999,  and  the number  increased  to  13,500  in

families with incomes near or below the poverty line, they lack opportunities for further studies.
A  well-developed  equivalency  system  for  TESD  programs  similar  to  the  Accreditation  and

school  to  another.  In addition,  it  will provide  a  means for people  who have  acquired  technical

particularly  those  who  do  not  finish  high  school  and  hence  would  not  normally  qualify  for
entrance  to  TESDA  programs.  Establishment  of  equivalency  programs  will  make  TESD  more
attractive  and  open  TESD  institutions  to  the  poor  and  those  who  want  to  improve  their
livelihood.

A.

Rationale

The Government’s Medium-Term Development Plan emphasizes “economic growth with
62.

the global economy. This policy calls for the development of a highly skilled workforce. To meet
these requirements, the TESD system, as the main provider of technicians and skilled workers,

1. 

Strengthening TESDA

In the context of skills training, the role of the Government should be able to perform key

Institutionalizing Quality Assurance Programs

67.
The  1998  PESS  found  that  skills  training  was  basically  on  the  right  track  in  the

quality assurance is occupational standards and certification, an area where the Philippines has
sound  experience  on  which  to  build.  TESDA  will  be  assisted  to  expand  the  system  by
developing  additional  standards  and  a  qualification  framework.  In  particular,  50  skills
assessment centers will be established within existing TESD institutions throughout the country.
The  centers  will  be  equipped  and,  in  some  cases,  facilities  will  be  renovated.  In  addition,
personnel of the centers will receive training in skills testing and assessing the quality of TESD
programs.

2. 

Devolving Training Functions to LGUs and NGOs

75.
A corollary of strengthening the central functions of TESDA is for TESDA to devolve its
direct training responsibilities to LGUs, communities, institutions, and NGOs. At present, TESDA
still  administers  58  technical,  vocational,  and  agricultural  schools  and  45 provincial  training
centers  through  its  regional  and  provincial  offices.  The  devolution  of  responsibilities  for  these
training  institutions  from  the  center  to  the  local  levels  is  expected  to  realize  several  benefits.
First, training programs can be linked better to the needs of local enterprises. Second, training
institutions  can become  more  self-financing.  In  short,  locally  controlled  training  institutions  will
have to be more responsible for finding their own markets and financing. The Project, therefore,
supports  implementation of  the  policy  of  devolving  the  training  function  from  TESDA  to  LGUs
and  other  institutions,  NGOs,  or  foundations.  Consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  assist
TESDA  in  the  formulation  of  strategies  and  plans  for  devolution.  In  addition,  the  Project  will
provide resources to (i) strengthen the management capacity of local staff who will be involved

 19

in  the  devolution  process,  and  (ii)  upgrade  the  facilities  of  the  project  public  institutions  in
preparation for devolution.

a. 

Developing the Management and Staff of Local Institutions

76.
One of the main requirements for successful devolution  is  to  prepare  the  management
and  staff  of  local  organizations,  and  of  the  training  institutions  themselves,  to  accept  the
additional responsibilities. The Project provides assistance to empower and equip personnel at
the  local  and  school  levels  to  manage  and  supervise  TESD  programs  that  are  responsive  to
local needs. Administrators, key school officials, and LGU personnel who will be involved in the
devolution process and responsible for planning, managing, and supervising TESD  institutions
and  programs  at  the  local  and  school  levels  will  undergo  training  to  be  organized  under  the
Project.  The  staff  development  programs  for  this  subcomponent  emphasize  planning,
management,  supervision,  and  assessment  of  TESD  institutions.  LGU  personnel  will  be
selected from among those  who  will  be  involved  in  implementing  the  devolution of  the  project
institutions.  School-based  supervisory,  monitoring,  and  evaluation  systems 
to  ensure
continuous  self-improvement  will be  institutionalized  in  the project  institutions.  These  activities
will enable LGUs and the project institutions to plan and manage their  skills  training programs
more effectively.

b. 

Developing the Training Facilities

77.

equip  and  prepare  themselves  for  the  devolution  process  and  to  become  more  independent

3. 

Strengthening the Capacity of Private TESD Providers

81.
The third objective of the Project is to enhance the quality and coverage of private skills
training. Private providers supply about 80 percent of all skills training at present. This is one of
the clear strengths of the system because private providers tend to be more closely linked to the
job market and save substantial public resources. However, the quality and coverage of private
provision are limited by lack of access to capital, which constrains the potential contribution  of
private  providers  to  the  sector.  The  Project  will  give  private  providers  access  to  a  financing
facility  for  quality  improvement  by  creating  the  Fund  for  Technical  Education  and  Skills
Development  (FTESD)  from  which  qualified  private  training  institutions  could  borrow.  The
FTESD  will  be  open  to  all  private  training  institutions  on  a  competitive  basis.  Interested
institutions can submit a project proposal showing the purposes for which the funds will be used
and  justifying  those  uses  in  terms  of  improving  the  quality  of  their  TESD  programs.  The
Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) will administer the FTESD and ensure repayment.
The  criteria for  allocating funds  include, among others,  relevance  of  the  proposed  program  to
priority  economic  requirements  (e.g.,  information  technology,  engineering  technology,  food
technology, tourism, etc.), technical and financial feasibility, and efficiency in the proposed use
of  funds,  financial  soundness  of  the  institution,  and  geographic  location.  Borrowers  will  be
required  to  enter  into  a  process  of  quality  upgrading  leading  to  full  accreditation  by  TESDA.
Details of DBP are in Appendix 11.

Minimum  and  maximum  amounts  are  expected  to  range  from  $25,000  to  $500,000.  A

a loan amount of up to 80 percent of total project costs, grace period of 6-24 months, maximum
terms  of  10  years,  and  an  interest  rate  of  11.5-14.0  percent,  to  be  fixed  in  accordance  with
market conditions at the time of approval, and a front-end fee of 1 percent of the loan amount. In

4.

Enhancing Equity in Skills Acquisition

83.
One consequence of the heavy reliance on private institutions for skills development  is
that the burden for financing the training falls on the students and trainees. Private institutions
typically  earmark  about  5  percent  of  tuition  revenues  for  scholarships.  Still,  many  potential
trainees  cannot  afford  the  direct  costs.  The  fourth  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  help  reduce
poverty through better acquisition of skills for income generation among the poor. Through the
establishment of a scholarship fund (SF) and a student loan fund (SLF), the Project will assist
disadvantaged groups to receive and complete skills training.

a. 

Scholarship Fund

The  Project  will  establish  an  SF  of  $6.5  million  to  provide  poor  students  with  financial
84.
assistance  to  attend  formal  and  nonformal  skills  training  in  public  and  private  institutions
(Appendix  6).  TESDA  will  administer  the  SF  and  make  disbursements  through  its  depository
bank, Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP). LBP has a wide network of branches throughout the
country .

85.
TESD  students  enrolled  in  priority  fields  such  as  engineering-related  subjects,
information  technology,  construction,  tourism,  foods,  and  agriculture  in  formal  and  nonformal
programs in public and private institutions—and from families below the official poverty line are
eligible to apply for scholarships at the schools where they want to enroll. TESDA will allocate
the assistance to the provincial offices, which, in turn, will allocate it to the recipients based on
applications from the training institutions. This is the procedure currently followed in the award
of PESFA scholarships to poor students. The school will evaluate the eligibility of the students
and determine the amount to be awarded to each. Scholarships will be a maximum of P14,500
per student per year and may be applied to tuition, books and  materials, and  living  expenses.
The school will decide, in consultation with the students and their parents/guardians, the priority
needs of the students and the allowances needed to cover their living expenses.

86.
Enrollees  in  nonformal  TESD  programs  will  be  given  the  scholarship  only  once  to
complete the program. For formal programs that require full-time studies leading to a certificate
or  diploma  below  the  degree  level,  the  support  may  be  extended  after  the  first  year  until  the
student  completes  the  program  provided  progress  is  satisfactory  and  completion  is  within  a
maximum  of  three  years.  The  school  will  be  required  to  submit  a  report  on  student  academic
performance to TESDA every term. Approximately 20,000 students/trainees will benefit from the
SF. The Government will also continue to support student assistance under the PESFA program
at least at the 1999 levels throughout the project period.

b.

Student Loan Fund

87.
Scholarship  grants  have  the  advantage  of  targeting  the  poorest  students  but  the
disadvantage of not being readily sustainable. Once the grant fund is exhausted, there may be
no  replenishment  even  though  there  will  be  a  continuing  demand  for  some  form  of  financial
support for  the  poorest  students.  In  addition,  while  scholarship  grants  target  the  poorest,  they
are  not  necessarily  appropriate  for  the  needs  of  the  borderline  poor,  that  is,  students  from
families whose income is too high to qualify the students for a scholarship grant but too low to
enable them to pursue technical or vocational studies. Scholarship grants have the  advantage
of being relatively simple to administer since repayment is not a factor, while loan funds, which
recycle resources, are associated with a certain amount of risk.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

126.
The Project responds to the requirements for competitiveness and equity; addresses key
weaknesses in the present TESD system, supports the implementation of well-conceived plans
for  skills  development,  takes  into  account  lessons  from  previous  assistance,  conforms  with
ADB’s  country  strategy  and  education  policies,  finances  soundly  designed  components  of  a
clear  project  strategy,  and  incorporates  feasible  financing  and  implementation  plans.  More
specific justification is given in the following paragraphs.

A. 

Economic Justification

127. Economic  analysis  determined  the  economic  viability  and  return  on  investment  for  the
Project. The economic internal rate of return is estimated at 14.6 percent, which is above ADB’s
standard  economic opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12 percent.  Sensitivity  tests  (with  10  percent
increase or decrease in project benefits) show a reduced internal rate of return of 11.6 percent.
The Project is viable from the national economic perspective (Appendix D).

B.

128.

and  curricula;  pursue  staff  development;  and  evaluate/disseminate  information  on  the
performance  of  the  system.  These  functions  are  properly  those  of  the  public  sector  and  the
central TESD coordinating agency. Assistance in these areas is justified by its multiplier effect

through  relatively  small  investments.  This  is  especially  true  for  badly  needed  quality
improvements. The Project will facilitate the implementation of a  well-conceived  system  where
employers drive the development of competency standards and skills acquisition through testing
and  certification.  In  total,  about 175,000  TESD  trainees  will  receive  improved  training  through
TESDA’s activities in course improvement, instructional materials, and staff development. These
quality  improvements  are  expected  to  result  in  significant  increases—on  the  order  of

C. 

Social Dimensions

131.
The  Project  is  also  justified  by  its  expected  contribution  to  poverty  reduction.  TESD
institutions  have  been  found  to  enroll  a  high  proportion  of  students  from  low-income  families.
The least financially able of these groups will qualify for scholarships and educational loans to
be provided under the Project. At least 25,000 students will complete their training with financial

summary, the Project is justified by its contributions to improve equity to TESD among the poor.
It  will  ensure  completion  of  training  and  acquisition  of  income-generating  skills  for  sizable

D.

Impact on Poverty

132.
The Project is designed to improve the quality of the technical workforce and to enhance
equitable  access  and  opportunities  for  the  poor  to  acquire  employable  skills.  In  addition  to
improving the quality of the TESD system as a whole, the Project will strengthen and enhance
training facilities and resources in all 13 regions of the country. It will provide scholarships and
loans to approximately 25,000 low income students, particularly women, to avail themselves of

 32

TESD training opportunities. The Project will strengthen linkages between TESD institutions and
private  businesses  and  industries.  It  will  also  help  institutionalize  career  guidance  and  job
placement services in the project institutions. These support services will help TESD graduates
find  appropriate  employment.  The  EMIS,  to  be  further  strengthened  under  the  Project,  will
enable TESD institutions to plan and manage their programs effectively. The EMIS  will  further
ensure that relevant training is provided to support a good match between the demand for and
supply  of  appropriate  skills  in  the  localities.  Overall,  the  Project  directly  addresses  poverty
issues among the poor who are the main clients and beneficiaries of the TESD system.

133.
Incremental benefits that will accrue to poor workers can be measured in terms of higher
income. Without the benefit of training, poor workers are  inclined  to  receive  wages  lower  than
the  nominal  minimum  wage  rate  of  $4.95  equivalent  per  day.  TESDA  studies  show  that  with
training, these workers are in a better position to get at least the minimum wage and higher in
most  cases.  The potential  income  of  the project  beneficiaries  would thus  range  from  $6.44  to
$9.90 equivalent per day. With additional skills and knowledge, those who will be self-employed
or  entrepreneurs  can  earn  higher  incomes.  The  financial  impact  of  the  Project  on  the
beneficiaries is relatively greater because the majority are unemployed or underemployed, and
have little or no forgone income during the training period. For them, the quality of life is likely to
be  improved.  In  addition,  staff  development  programs  will  enhance  the  marketability  of  the
trainers and will help improve their incomes.

134.
The  impact  of  the  Project  on  poverty  can  be  assessed  on  the  following  criteria:
(i) number of students/trainees from families below the official poverty line enrolled in public and
private  TESD  institutions;  (ii)  the  gender  ratio  of  students/trainees  in  TESD  programs;  (iii)
number and ratio of TESD students from the disadvantaged and minority groups; (iv) number of
poor  who  receive  scholarships  and  educational  loans  to  attend  TESD  institutions  under  the
Project; (v) number of TESD graduates employed or self-employed, their occupations, and their
income levels after graduation, particularly the poor who received scholarships; and (vi) number
of  graduates  who  find  better  jobs  and  employment  opportunities,  or  start  their  own  business
enterprises that help create jobs and generate employment in the communities.

135.
The impact of the Project on poverty reduction will  be  closely  monitored and assessed
through  the benefit  monitoring and evaluation  system  to  be  developed  under  the  Project.  The
project  impact  will  be  measured  on  the  basis  of  national  and  provincial  poverty  incidence.
Impact  tracer  studies  will  also  assess  the  overlap  of  benefits  to  families  and  to  spin-offs  of
employment  created  by  graduate  entrepreneurship.  These  measures  will  be  incorporated  into
the overall EMIS to be developed under the Project.

F.

Risks

Three main risks exist for the Project. First, training institutions risk loss of quality as they
138.
move from TESDA to local or self-administration. That is because TESDA has staff with higher
qualifications and often allocates  more  resources  to  institutions  under  its direct administration.
The Project counters this risk by providing ample staff development for local governments and
administrators  of  training  institutions,  and  assistance  to  build  training  facilities.  Recent
innovations also provide a basis for monitoring quality, e.g.,  competency-based  training  with  a
check on exit quality through testing. These will be improved and expanded under the Project.
TESDA will check quality trends and advise on remedial actions should any significant decline in
quality occur.

139. Second, a project of this size and diversity inevitably faces implementation risks. It could
be too much for one organization to manage. This risk is minimized because the organizations
(DBP  and  LBP)  that  will  handle  two  main  project  components—FTESD  and  the  SF—have
extensive experience in handling similar programs. In addition, the main implementing agency,
TESDA, has had experience in implementing externally financed projects. Its performance in the
recently  completed World Bank-financed  Second  Vocational  Training  Project  was  rated  highly
satisfactory.

140.
Third, risk is associated with the capacity and willingness of the LGUs, other government
agencies,  NGOs,  and  the  local  communities  to  adopt,  finance,  and  effectively  manage  the
devolved project institutions. To counter this potential risk, TESDA has already initiated dialogue
with the agencies concerned and will develop a comprehensive devolution plan in consultation
with LGUs and other agencies. Initially, it is expected that selected schools among the  project
institutions  would  serve  as  pilot  cases.  But,  based  on  experience  and  lessons  learned,  a
devolution scheme will be implemented more widely.

141. Other risks exist, but they are considered minor. Private training institutions may not, in
the end, avail themselves of the loan funds available for quality improvements under the Project.
However,  such an outcome  would  contradict  the  current evidence of  capital  constraints  in  the
feasibility  study  carried  out  in  1999.  If  loan  uptake  is  low,  ADB  and  DBP  will  investigate  the
reasons and amend the terms accordingly. DBP will carefully assess the financial soundness of
the potential borrowers to assure full repayments of the loans and interest. Improper targeting of
scholarships  could  also  occur,  but  this  has  not  been  a  problem  under  present  schemes.
Recipients of educational loans may fail to repay their dues but mechanisms have been built in
to  enhance  higher  rates  of  repayment.  Similarly,  a  risk  exists  that  the  Government—facing
budget shortages—will cut PESFA scholarships. An assurance included in the Project cements
the commitment to continue, at least at the present level.

Rationale. Many private technical education and skills development (TESD) institutions
need  to  improve  the  quality  of  their  programs.  To  assist  these  institutions,  which  enroll

Education and Skills Development (FTESD) to provide loans to eligible institutions.

2.
Scope  and  objectives.  From  FTESD the  Development  Bank  of  the  Philippines  (DBP)
will provide subloans to eligible private TESD institutions that will use the loan funds to procure
equipment and instructional materials, improve courses and programs, set up staff development
programs, and upgrade facilities but excluding the construction of new buildings.

Source  of  fund.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  a  loan  of

with DBP will first register their programs with TESDA for subsequent program assessment and
